Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 12:36AM flyfire444 wrote: Sueps... forgot to mention, I had the same diagnosis as you.  Only difference is that they did not take all my lymph nodes.  Only took a couple and found no C, so left the rest alone.  Your doctor must feel that your C is a slow growing type, mine was Her2N positive. He/she must feel there is no down side to your waiting several weeks for surgery.  If it was the States, the Onc would have you scheduled right away.  With BC, the oncs, don't mess around here.  They know the patients are already quite nervous and distraught and they want to do everything possible to get them calm in preparation for surgery.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 12:28AM flyfire444 wrote: Sue, I am also a "survivor" having had bc, chemo, radiation and now taking tamoxifen and vagifem among other sundry other drugs to manage side effects.  However, I am here, I'm alive and now enjoying my four week old grandson.  I went through similar feelings of dispair, darkness, and depression and I was very pleased to have a great Onc who was easy to talk to. He was very sensitive to my issues and readily prescribed anti-depressants, recommended a therapist, and most importantly reminded me of all my love support.  You, too, must re-connect with your loved ones. We are strong, we are women all sharing the same pain, same thoughts and hopes.  I'm not sure of your belief system, but I found meditation and prayer very helpful.  The hospital onc nurses kept in touch with symposiums, group meetings and just feel-good gatherings.  Don't be afraid to reach out to others in your home town going through the same issues.  There are many of us.  And many of us who have a strong will to survive and beat this beast known as Cancer.  Be blessed Sueps.
